revision_history.draft:
The scent of ink dissolves in the air,  
A clock’s teeth gnaw the hour into dust.  
Your voice, a fossil, hums in the hollow where  
the shelf holds your name in a language of scars.  

The pendulum’s sigh is a thread pulled taut,  
Between the seconds that never quite fall.  
A photograph bleeds its edges to gray,  
While the mirror forgets your face was there.  

Your heartbeat, a paused note, swells then fades  
In the silence where all echoes are erased.  
We leave behind only the dust we can’t name  
And the weight of a clock’s unspoken blame.

The scent of ink dissolves in the air,  
A clock’s teeth gnaw the hour into dust.  
Your voice, a fossil, hums in the hollow where  
the shelf holds your name in a script of scars.  

The pendulum’s sigh is a thread pulled taut,  
Between seconds that never quite fall.  
A photograph bleeds its edges to gray,  
While the mirror erases your face entirely.  

Your heartbeat, a frozen note, swells then fades  
In the silence where all echoes are erased.  
We leave behind only the dust we can’t name  
And the weight of a clock’s unspoken weight.

final_poem:
The scent of ink dissolves in the air,  
A clock’s teeth gnaw the hour into dust.  
Your voice, a fossil, hums in the hollow where  
the shelf holds your name in a script of scars.  

The pendulum’s sigh is a thread pulled taut,  
Between seconds that never quite fall.  
A photograph bleeds its edges to gray,  
While the mirror erases your face entirely.  

Your heartbeat, a frozen note, swells then fades  
In the silence where all echoes are erased.  
We leave behind only the dust we can’t name  
And the weight of a clock’s unspoken weight.
